Situation1: Include each other in social activities and outings when possible.
Expectation2: Educate the public and the community about their cause.
Situation2: A social media post about your cause is currently going viral, and now is the perfect moment to add a comment with more information.
Story: My phone buzzes with notifications as I sit on the edge of my bed, lacing up my shoes. My sister calls from the hallway, “Are you ready? Everyone’s waiting for us!” We’d planned this outing for weeks—a rare chance to spend time together, just the two of us and some friends. I know how much it means to her that I show up, that I make her feel included and important. But as I grab my jacket, I see my phone screen light up again. The post about our cause is exploding online. This is the moment I’ve been waiting for, the chance to educate thousands, maybe more, if I just add the right comment now. My activist friends are tagging me, urging me to respond before the momentum fades. I feel the weight of both worlds pressing on me—my sister’s hopeful voice, the urgent pings from my activist group. I want to be present for her, to build the trust we’ve worked so hard for, but I also feel the responsibility to my cause, to the people counting on me to speak up. My heart pounds as I stand in the doorway, torn between two calls I can’t ignore.
